TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit BitmapCacheBrush extends System.Windows.Media.Brush
Public NotInheritable Class BitmapCacheBrush Inherits Brush
public ref class BitmapCacheBrush sealed : System::Windows::Media::Brush
.class public auto ansi sealed BitmapCacheBrush extends System.Windows.Media.Brush

Docs.summary: Paints an area with cached content.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> class to reuse a cached element efficiently. This is useful when you need to paint complex content onto multiple elements. Use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache> class to cache a complex element.
Assign a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual> to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.Target%2A> property and optionally assign a <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache> to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.BitmapCache%2A> property. The <xref:System.Windows.Media.CacheMode> of the brush and the target <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual> interact to produce different behaviors. The following table describes this interaction.
||Target has no CacheMode|Target has CacheMode| |-|-----------------------------|--------------------------| |Brush has no CacheMode|Target visual renders normally; brush uses default cache behavior.|Target visual renders into its own cache; brush uses target's cache when rendering.| |Brush has CacheMode|Target visual renders normally; brush renders target into its own cache and uses this to render.|Target visual renders into its own cache; brush renders target into brush's own cache and uses this to render.|
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> class is similar to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.VisualBrush> class, but <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> always renders from a cache on the target element, or from a cache defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.BitmapCache%2A> property. The <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> class also supports dirty regions.
The following table shows the default bitmap cache settings for the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> class.
|Bitmap Cache Property|Default Setting| |---------------------------|---------------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.SnapsToDevicePixels%2A>|`false`| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.EnableClearType%2A>|`false`| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.RenderAtScale%2A>|1|
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.SnapsToDevicePixels%2A> property is ignored by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> class.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> class ignores the following properties on the root <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual>. This behavior differs from the <xref:System.Windows.Media.VisualBrush> class.
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualOffset%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualTransform%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualClip%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualEffect%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualOpacity%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualOpacityMask%2A>
## Examples The following code example shows how to associate a <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache> with a <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush>. You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> resource on multiple elements and achieve good performance. For the complete code listing, see [How to: Use a Cached Element as a Brush](/dotnet/framework/wpf/graphics-multimedia/how-to-use-a-cached-element-as-a-brush).

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether layout is applied to the contents of this brush.
Docs.value: if layout is applied; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.AutoLayoutContent%2A> property is `true`, layout is applied to the contents of the brush if <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.Target%2A> is a <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> with no parent.
